DOC.HEAD: Romanians Can't Afford to Purge Party
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Many Romanians who have thrown off the yoke of their dictator want to make a clean break with the past, but the new leadership says the country can't afford to purge former Communist Party members. In Romania, virtually everyone in a leading position was required to be a party member. And party membership, government officials say, is not a mark of ideology. ``Many Communist Party members are indespensible,'' said Cazimir Ionescu, one of the vice presidents of the provisional government. ``We have not followed the old system of looking at dossiers,'' Ionescu said at a news conference. The Communist Party has become a hated reminder in Romania of the 24 years of Nicolae Ceausscu, who was overthrown, captured and executed in a bloody revolution that came so swiftly the country has had no time to plan its future. ``Jos Comunismul'' _ ``Down with Communism'' _ is a slogan that now appears on posters and scrawled on walls around the captial. Romanians in the street say they want to wipe the words Communist Party from their mind and language. ``Communism is shame and it should be destroyed everywhere,'' said Gheorghe Chelaru, who described himself only as a worker. But members of the provisional government say they are trying to run a country and an economy. They need managers and organizers with a proven record. In Romania, all those people once belonged to the party. The new government is trying to take people on the basis of merit, not their past, said Ionescu. Prominent ex-Communists in the new leadership include President Ion Iliescu, former Ambassador to the United States Silviu Brucan, and former Foreign Minister Corneliu Manescu. Dumitru Mazilu, another leading figure, was a diplomat who was under house arrest for most of the last two years because he refused to doctor a report for the U.N. Human Rights Commission in Geneva. Even the poet Mircea Dinescu, one of the country's leading dissidents, was a member of the party, until last spring. ``The party doesn't exist anymore. Where do you see the party? How can it contribute to the revolution? We don't know. We didn't ask those who came to the palace (to join the revolution), Are you Communists?'' said deputy Foreign Minister Corneliu Bogdan. ``I myself was a member of the party.'' ``If we begin to count by number, then I think you are missing the point,'' he told journalists who repeatedly asked how many former Communists are in the new leadership. Bogdan and Ionescu said the new government was committed to ending the abuses of Ceausescu. They pointed out that the government moved quickly to repeal some of the most hated laws. Romanians are free to travel, ration cards have been eliminated and food once destined for export has been redirected to the shops. Ionescu and Bogdan say they are committed to democracy, to opening a free market and to holding free elections by April. The government officials say if the people don't like the former Communists, they can vote them out.
